0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (through age 55 years) 0.5 mL IM as a single dose (manufacturer dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (through age 55 years with high-risk conditions) 0.5 mL IM as 2-dose series, given at least 2 months apart (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (revaccination of adults who remain at increased risk for infection) 0.5 mL IM every 5 years
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (56 years or older; revaccination or person previously vaccinated with Menveo(R)) 0.5 mL IM

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (Initiating at 2 months of age): 0.5 mL IM as a 4-dose series at 2, 4, 6, and 12 months of age (manufacturer dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (initiating at 8 weeks to 6 months with high-risk conditions) 4-dose series given at 2, 4, 6, and 12 months of age (guideline dosing)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (7 to 23 months of age with high-risk conditions and previously unvaccinated): 2 doses at least 12 weeks apart and second dose after the first birthday (guideline dosing)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (2 years or older with high-risk conditions, who have not received a complete vaccine series): 2-dose series, given at least 8 weeks apart (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (11 through 12 years) give single dose and a booster dose at age 16 years (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (11 through 18 years, with HIV) 2-dose series, given at least 8 weeks apart (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: Catch-up: Vaccinate at 13 to 18 years if not previously vaccinated (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: Catch-up: If first dose was given at age 13 to 15 years, give booster dose at age 16 to 18 years, with at least 8 weeks between doses; if first dose is given at age 16 years or older, a booster dose is not required (guideline dose)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: allergic reactions, severe (eg, anaphylaxis), after a previous dose of meningococcal oligosaccharide vaccine, diphtheria conjugate, any component of the vaccine or any other CRM-197 protein, diphtheria toxoid or meningococcal-containing vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, acute; appropriate supportive medical treatment should be readily available during treatment
  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) has been reported in association with administration of meningococcal quadrivalent polysaccharide conjugate vaccine
  • immunocompromised individuals, including receipt of immunosuppressive therapy; expected immune response may not be obtained
  • infants, premature; increased risk of apnea
  • syncope, sometimes associated with seizure-like activity, has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse events to Novartis Vaccines at 1-877-683-4732 or to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema (adult, 16%; pediatric, 11% to 28%), Injection site pain (adult, 38% to 41%; pediatric, 28% to 44%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (infants, 8% to 16%), Nausea (adult, 7% to 10%; pediatric, 8% to 12%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myalgia (adult, 14% to 18%; pediatric, 10% to 19%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (adult, 25% to 30%; pediatric, 5% to 29%), Somnolence (pediatric, 12% to 50%)
  • Psychiatric:Crying, excessive (infant, 21% to 41%), Irritability (pediatric, 16% to 57%)
  • Other:Malaise (adult, 10% to 16%; pediatric, 11% to 14%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Vaccination with meningococcal oligosaccharide vaccine, diphtheria conjugate leads to the production of bactericidal antibodies that protects against invasive meningococcal disease.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IM use only; do not give subQ, IV, or intradermally
  • Intramuscular
    • reconstitute with supplied diluent, shake well to dissolve; use immediately or store below 77 F (25 C) for up to 8 hours
    • administer IM into the anterolateral aspect of the thigh (infants) or the deltoid muscle (toddlers, adolescents, adults)
    • do not mix with any other vaccine

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: signs/symptoms of syncope for 15 min following administration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• In adolescents and adults, drug may cause injection site pain, headaches, myalgia, malaise, and nausea.
  • In infants and children, drug may cause injection site erythema/pain, irritability, sleepiness, persistent crying, diarrhea, and vomiting.
  • Inform infant or child caregiver that receiving the entire series of vaccinations is important for effectiveness.
